bibl.title: Memorandum from Albert G. Love to the Board of Governors, Walter Reed Memorial Association, December 14, 1950

div1.p: This memorandum records the minutes from the annual meeting of the Walter Reed Memorial Association. Included is a discussion of Blossom Reed's situation and the ongoing effort to publicize Reed's work.

div1.head: Memorandum from Albert G. Love to the Board of Governors, Walter Reed Memorial Association, December 14, 1950
div1.p:
MINUTES
ANNUAL MEETING, BOARD OF MANAGERS, WALTER REED MEMORIAL ASSOCIATION
Washington, D. C., December 14, 1950

The Board met at 10 A.M., in the Board Room, American Security and Trust
Company, 15th Street and Pennsylvania Avenue, Northwest, Washington, D. C.

The Board had suffered an irreparable loss as a result of the death of its
President, Brig. Gen. Jefferson R. Kean, on September 4, 1950. The Vice President,
Maj. Gen. M. W. Ireland was unable to be present on account of illness in hospital.
The Secretary of the Board was requested to preside, temporarily, pending the
election of officers. Col. J. F. Siler, the Secretary, called the meeting to order.

The following members were present: Maj. Gen. R. W. Bliss, Dr. Gilbert
Grosvenor, Mr. Hans W. Ireland, Brig. Gen. F. R. Keefer, Brig. Gen. Albert G. Love,
Col. J. F. Siler, and Dr. Fred W. Soper. Absent: Dr. Philip S. Hench, Maj. Gen.
M. W. Ireland and Maj. Gen. C. R. Reynolds.

It was unanimously voted that an expression of the grief and deep sense of
loss suffered by the Association and its Board of Managers in the loss of its
President, Brig. Gen. Jefferson R. Kean, who died September 4, 1950, be spread upon
the minutes of the meeting and that a letter of sympathy be sent to the widow.

The minutes of the last annual meeting had been mailed to all members. In
view of the fact that no suggestions had been received relative to corrections or
amendments, it was moved and seconded that reading of the minutes be dispensed with
and that they be approved as recorded. The motion was carried unanimously.
The Treasurer submitted the following report which was approved

div1.p:
The next order of business was the election of officers and new members.
The nominating committee presented the following report:

Washington, D. C.
December 14, 1950
TO: The Board of Managers of the Walter Reed Memorial Association
SUBJECT: Report of an Advisory Nominating Committee

list.item:
1. As the result of the death of our beloved and honored President,
Brig. Gen. J. R. Kean, it is necessary that we elect a new President.

2. In addition, it seems desirable in view of the continued incapacity
of our beloved and honored Vice President, Maj. Gen. M. W. Ireland,
to elect a new Vice President.

3. Dr. L. O. Howard, one of our esteemed members has passed on. As a
result of his death and of that of Gen. Kean, there are two member
vacancies. Consequently the Secretary and Acting President of the
Association, Col. J. F. Siler, on December 12, 1950, requested Mr.
Hans W. Ireland, Treasurer and Brig. Gen. Albert G. Love to act as
an Advisory Nominating Committee.

div1.p:
The Committee submits the following suggestions:
1. President, Col. J. F. Siler
2. Vice President, Dr. Philip S. Hench
3. Since it obviously would be unfair to ask Col. Siler to assume the
duties as President and also to continue those as Secretary, the
Committee suggests that his resignation as Secretary be accepted
after his election as President, and that then Brig. Gen. Albert
G. Love be elected as Secretary.
4. Hans W. Ireland, Treasurer
5. To fill the member vacancies caused by the deaths of Brig. Gen. J. R.
Kean and Dr. L. O. Howard, the following names are submitted:
Vice Admiral Ross T. McIntyre, USN Rtd.
Maj. Gen. Paul H. Streit, MC USA
Both of these distinguished officers have expressed their willingness
to serve.

Hans W. Ireland, Advisory Nominating
Committee

Albert G. Love, Advisory Nominating
Committee

The chairman asked if any member desired to make any other nominations. None
were made. He then requested General Bliss to take the chair for action on the
report of the nominating committee. It was then moved and seconded that the report
of the nominating committee be accepted and approved. The motion was carried
unanimously.

Colonel Siler stated that he felt that he was very highly honored in being
made President of the Association and that he would make every effort to carry out
the wishes of the Association.

The President stated that, as a rule, annual meetings were held on or about
the day of the month on which Walter Reed died, namely, November 23. The annual
meeting for this year was held in abeyance, temporarily, in the hope that it might
be possible for Dr. Hench to stop over for the meeting on his return from one of
the two visits to Europe that he had to make this fall, the latter of which was to
receive one of the Nobel Prize Awards. A letter received from him recently advised
that, to his regret, it would not be practicable for him to visit Washington until
next spring.

The Chairman stated that all members of the Board were aware of the death of
Mrs. Walter Reed on July 23, 1950, at the age of 95. Graveside services were held
at Arlington National Cemetery and flowers were sent on behalf of the Board. He
also stated that the monthly allowance of income from assets of the Association,
formerly sent Mrs. Walter Reed, was now being sent each month to Mrs. Blossom Reed,
in compliance with the provisions of the certificate of incorporation and the
resolution adopted at the annual meeting in 1949.

The Chairman stated that he desired to review briefly the progress made in the
solution of some of the matters discussed at the last annual meeting.

At last year's annual meeting it was decided definitely that a bronze plaque, to
be purchased by the Association, would be placed in front of the building in which
Walter Reed died in 1902. The inscription to be carved on the plaque, suggested at
the meeting, was not deemed entirely satisfactory and it was decided that the exact
wording required further consideration. Subsequent to further consultations with
members of the Board, it was agreed that the following wording would be used:
WALTER REED
WHO GAVE MAN CONTROL OVER YELLOW FEVER
DIED IN A HOSPITAL
ON THIS SITE
November 23, 1902
The authorities at Ft. Lesley McNair cooperated wholeheartedly in preparing a base
for and installing the plaque. Immediately after its installation the plaque was
inspected by Maj. Gen. W. L. Reed, Brig. Gen. Albert G. Love and Col. Siler and was
considered entirely satisfactory. In the immediate future, it is the intention to
secure a photograph of the plaque and its immediate surroundings and send a print
to each member of the Board.

Another matter brought up by Dr. Hench last year was that of arranging for the
publication of information relating to Walter Reed and his work on yellow fever during
this - the fiftieth anniversary of his work in Cuba. It is a most interesting fact
that this year marks the 50th anniversary of Walter Reed's work in Cuba, that 1951
will be the 100th anniversary of his birth and that 1952 will be the 50th anniversary
of his death.

More than a year ago a resolution was introduced in the Congress by Congress-
man Bland of Virginia and Senator Jenner, providing for the expenditure of $350,000.
in a three year period to better acquaint the American people with the researches
made by Walter Reed relative to the method of transmission of yellow fever and its
control. No action was taken by the Congress. Last summer Mr. Frank Carey, a
Washington correspondent of the Associated Press, advised me that he was preparing
an article on Walter Reed. We loaned him a number of published articles relating
to Walter Reed's work and he secured other data during an interview with General Kean.
His article appeared locally in the Washington Post on June 25, 1950, and was sent
out over Associated Press wire to some 1500 newspapers.

On August 29th the Secretary received a letter from Mr. Sidney Wallach, the head
of a publicity firm in New York City (The Wallach Associates) advising him that Mr.
Wallach contemplated raising a fund of $50,000. or more to be used for the preparation
of articles on Walter Reed to be published in journals and newspapers and he desired
to secure the cooperation and support of the Walter Reed Memorial Association. He
came to Washington on October 4th, 1950 and outlined his plans to the following
members of the Board: Gen. Keefer, Gen. Love, Mr. Ireland and Col. Siler. No
definite action was taken and he was requested to submit his plans in writing for
action by the Board at this annual meeting. No further information has been
received from him.

The fourth matter referred to by Dr. Hench, the preservation of one of the
buildings used by Walter Reed in his yellow fever transmission work in Cuba as a
permanent memorial, is still held in abeyance pending a visit to Washington by
Dr. Hench when he can consult with Gen. Bliss and other military and State Department
officials.

There being no further business, the meeting was adjourned to meet at the call
of the President.

closer.signed:
Albert G. Love,
Brig. Gen., U.S.A. Retired
Secretary
